subject: Surgery and Surgeons
lead_paragraph: The former cyclist Davis Phinney, 48, had successful surgery to help treat his Parkinson’s disease on Friday, the same day the International Cycling Union released rankings that confirmed Phinney’s 17-year-old son, Taylor, was about to become a United States Olympian. Surgeons at Stanford University Medical Center in Palo Alto, Calif., spent about four and a half hours embedding two wires in a section of Davis Phinney’s brain, without complication. Next week, they will attach a pacemaker to the wires; doctors have said they believe that when the machine is turned on later this month, it will relieve some of his symptoms.
